Expectation1: Assist patients with daily living activities such as bathing, dressing, and eating
Situation1: The nursing assistant is on their morning rounds to help a patient with their daily routine.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I was halfway through my morning rounds at the care home, helping Mrs. Lee with her breakfast and making sure she was comfortable. My mind was already racing, knowing today was Election Day and I had to vote before my shift ended. As soon as I finished with Mrs. Lee, I rushed to the polling station, still in my scrubs, hoping to make it back before the next round of medication checks. At the polling booth, the worker handed back my ballot envelope, pointing out a smudge on my signature. “Could you please re-sign this? Otherwise, your vote might not count,” she said. I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of my responsibilities tugging at me. If I took the time to fix the ballot, I’d be late returning to the care home, and my patients depended on me for their morning care. But if I rushed back, my vote might not be counted. I stood there, pen in hand, torn between my duty to my patients and my responsibility as a voter, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in on me.
